questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. A Pap smear 4 years ago showed no abnormalities. She was treated for a chlamydia infection at 22 years of age. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A Pap smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An endometrial biopsy is recommended for all nonpregnant individuals ≥ 35 years of age with atypical glandular cells (AGCs) or adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) to rule out endometrial cancer. Endometrial biopsy is also recommended for nonpregnant individuals < 35 years of age with AGCs or AIS and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial cancer. This patient has atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, and therefore endometrial biopsy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Expedited excisional treatment (e.g., with loop electrosurgical excision procedure) is indicated for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required. In addition, as this patient has a low-grade cervical cytology, it is unlikely that excisional treatment will be required.

C) CORRECT:

If the initial primary HPV test or cytology-alone test is positive, reflex triage testing (i.e., cytology if HPV testing is positive and HPV testing if cytology is positive) should be performed for risk stratification. In patients with positive cytology-alone screening, reflex high-risk HPV genotyping is indicated to assess for HPV 16 or HPV 18 infection. Recommendations for further follow-up are based on the estimated risk for CIN3+.

If atypical glandular cells are found on initial cytology, reflex HPV testing is not required, as management is independent of HPV status.

D) INCORRECT:

Performing cytology in 3 years is the standard screening interval for cytology-alone screening for cervical cancer. This would be appropriate if this patient's cytology results were normal. However, this patient has positive cytology and the immediate risk of CIN3+ must be determined before deciding whether it is appropriate to resume routine screening.

E) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy and cervical biopsy may be considered for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required.
questions.hint: In patients with positive cytology, an additional step is required to assess the immediate risk of CIN3+.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 5 days. The first day of her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Pap smear now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every year, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF, a Pap smear every 3 years in individuals with a cervix who are 21–29 years of age is an acceptable screening method for cervical cancer. However, an additional test is required as a part of cervical cancer screening starting at the age of 30 years. In addition, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, this patient should now receive HPV testing along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should not be repeated annually because more frequent testing does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

C) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening every 5 years starting at 30 years of age. However, when screening every 5 years, the protocol requires another test in addition to the Pap smear. If the additional test cannot be performed, a Pap smear should be taken every 3 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

E) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years for individuals with a cervix who are 30–65 years of age and a solitary Pap smear every 3 years for those between 21–29 years of age. This guidance differs from the recently updated ASCCP, ACS, and ACOG guidelines, which recommend that those aged 25–65 years undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (where available) or HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years. All guidelines recommend a solitary Pap smear every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable.

Regarding breast cancer, mammography is rarely useful in younger patients, who have naturally denser breast tissue. According to the USPSTF, breast cancer screening with mammography should be performed every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Screening can be started earlier in patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancer. Breast cancer screening recommendations may differ between medical organizations (e.g., ACOG, ACS). Consult our table “Breast cancer screening for individuals at average risk” for the most up-to-date information on breast cancer screening recommendations.

Whenever the information required to determine the correct answer for an NBME question involves a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF recommendations.

F) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies. Moreover, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.
questions.hint: This patient is healthy and requires the standard screening tests for her age group and risk stratification according to USPSTF guidelines.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. She reports feeling nauseated and has vomited several times over the past week. During this period, she has also had increased urinary frequency. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and they use condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A serum pregnancy test is positive. HPV testing is positive. A Pap smear shows a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Colposcopy and cervical biopsy show cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II and III. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Colposcopy and HPV-based testing in 12 weeks
Expedited treatment with loop electrosurgical excision

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In pregnant women with high-grade precancerous lesions (i.e., CIN2 or CIN3), colposcopic surveillance with HPV-based testing every 12–24 weeks is preferred. Deferring colposcopy until ≥ 4 weeks after delivery is also an acceptable approach. The management of pregnant individuals with high-grade lesions differs from that of nonpregnant patients: treatment of premalignant lesions can safely be deferred until the postpartum period; expedited treatment for HSIL is contraindicated during pregnancy. A repeat biopsy should be performed if the cervical lesion appears to be worsening on colposcopic surveillance. An excisional procedure should be considered only if invasive cancer is suspected.

Colposcopy and biopsy are safe during pregnancy but endocervical curettage and endometrial biopsies are contraindicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Cold-knife conization is used in the management of high-grade cervical abnormalities and early-stage cervical cancer. Cold-knife conization is contraindicated during pregnancy but can be safely performed 4 weeks after birth. However, before any cervical excision procedure, repeat colposcopic evaluation needs to re-confirm the need for excision.

C) INCORRECT:

Endocervical curettage (ECC) is usually performed in women with high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) to allow sampling of the endocervical canal. The procedure may identify contiguous and noncontiguous ("skip") lesions. ECC is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may cause potential trauma to the gestational sac and heavy bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Expedited treatment (e.g., with loop surgical excision) is indicated in nonpregnant women with a high immediate risk of CIN III+ risk (e.g., patients with high-grade cervical lesions and positive HPV testing). However, during pregnancy, excisional treatment is only considered if cancer is suspected as excisional procedures increase the risk of poor pregnancy outcomes (e.g., abortion, preterm labor).

E) INCORRECT:

In pregnancy, repeat cervical biopsy is only indicated if invasion is suspected, which is not the case here, or if the cervical lesion appears to be worsening on surveillance.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient presents with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) on Pap smear and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) II and CIN III on histology.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Her last visit was 3 years ago. She feels well. One year ago, she underwent a bilateral salpingectomy after the delivery of her third child. She does not take any medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A Pap smear shows a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. HPV testing is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Cytology and HPV testing after 12 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeat cytology (Pap smear) at three months is only indicated in cases in which the Pap smear is found unsatisfactory for evaluation. This is not the case in this patient, as a finding of HSIL has already been established based on her Pap smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Expedited treatment is appropriate in patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. While ablation is one possible treatment option, another treatment is preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

One-year follow-up with cytology and HPV testing is appropriate for patients with a low immediate risk of CIN3+ (e.g., low-grade cytology and negative HPV testing). For patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+, one-year follow-up is not appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+, expedited treatment (i.e., treatment without a preceding colposcopy with cervical biopsy and histological confirmation) is preferred. Excisional treatment (e.g., loop electrosurgical excision procedure) is preferred over ablation because it provides a tissue sample, and histopathological examination can assess margin status and allows for the detection of higher grade abnormalities. Performing a colposcopy with cervical biopsy before treatment is also a reasonable approach for patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+.

E) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy with cervical biopsy is an acceptable approach in patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. However, endometrial biopsy is not indicated in this patient. Endometrial biopsy is indicated in patients aged ≥ 35 years with atypical glandular cells on cytology or adenocarcinoma in situ. For patients aged < 35 years with these findings, endometrial biopsy is recommended if the patient also has abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial neoplasia (e.g., obesity, chronic anovulation).
questions.hint: A high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) on cytology with positive HPV testing is a predictor of a high immediate risk of CIN3+.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine gynecological examination. She feels well. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 3 to 5 days with normal flow. Her last menstrual period was 20 days ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 40 years. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and occasionally drinks a glass of wine with dinner. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A Pap smear shows atypical glandular cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform colposcopy with endocervical and endometrial sampling
Perform a diagnostic loop electrosurgical excision

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One-year follow-up is appropriate for patients with a low immediate risk of CIN3+ lesions (e.g., patients with low-grade cytology and negative HPV testing) but should include both cytology and HPV testing. Additionally, the presence of AGCs on cytology should raise concern for endometrial cancer, making a different step more appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Colposcopy with endocervical sampling is appropriate for all nonpregnant patients with AGCs to rule out cervical cancer, regardless of HPV test results. In addition, endometrial sampling should be performed in nonpregnant patients with AGCs who are ≥ 35 years of age and in nonpregnant patients aged < 35 years with AGCs and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial neoplasia (e.g., obesity, chronic anovulation) to rule out endometrial cancer.

Endocervical and endometrial sampling are contraindicated in pregnancy because of the increased risk of complications (e.g., cervical or membrane perforation, pregnancy loss).

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic excisional procedures such as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) are indicated in patients with a very high immediate risk of CIN 3+ lesions based on initial cytology and HPV testing. This patient has AGCs and therefore a different step should be performed before an excisional procedure is considered.

D) INCORRECT:

HPV testing is not required for patients with AGCs, as HPV status does not influence the course of management. HPV testing may be performed during the initial routine screening for cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with AGCs on Pap smear should urgently undergo colposcopy with endocervical sampling to rule out cervical squamous intraepithelial lesions and cervical adenocarcinoma in situ. However, in patients ≥ 35 years of age with AGCs on Pap smear, an additional procedure should be performed.
questions.hint: Consider the age of the patient and the cytology findings of atypical glandular cells (AGCs) to determine the next best step.

questions.text: Three weeks after a loop electrosurgical excision procedure for cervical dysplasia, a 31-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. A pathology report confirms the presence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia II (CIN II) with clear surgical margins. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She lives with her boyfriend and they are planning to have a child soon. She feels well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vulva and vagina. Speculum examination shows cicatrized tissue on the cervix. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Pap smear and HPV testing in 5 years

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cytology-alone screening every 3 years is recommended for routine cervical cancer screening. This patient, however, had confirmed CIN and underwent loop excision. Follow-up of patients after ablation or loop excision should be done with an HPV-based test sooner than 3 years. Alternatively, annual cytology-alone surveillance is acceptable if HPV-based testing is not available.

B) INCORRECT:

An HPV-based test (i.e., primary HPV testing or cotesting with a Pap smear and HPV test) every 5 years is recommended for routine cervical cancer screening in women between 30 and 65 years of age. This patient, however, had confirmed CIN and underwent loop excision. Followup of patients after ablation or loop excision should be done with an HPV-based test but much sooner.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer screening is not necessary for average-risk patients > 65 years of age who have undergone appropriate screening tests and show no signs of CIN II or higher-grade dysplasia. However, this patient is 31 years old and has CIN II, which warrants further evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Regardless of the CIN grade before the procedure or the patient's previous HPV status, an HPV-based test (i.e., primary HPV testing or cotesting with a Pap smear and HPV test) in 6 months is the most appropriate next step for follow-up in patients ≥ 25 years of age after a cervical excisional or ablative procedure with clear margins. In these patients, the posttreatment high-risk HPV status at the procedural site is a much stronger predictor of the risk of recurrence than cytology alone. Annual cytology-alone surveillance is acceptable if HPV-based testing is not available. Solitary Pap smear (i.e., cervical cytology alone) at 6 months after treatment is used for follow-up of patients < 25 years of age.

Patients who test positive for HPV require further evaluation with colposcopy and cervical biopsy. Those who test negative require annual re-evaluation of their HPV status for another 3 years. If their HPV test results remain negative during this period, patients should be further tested for HPV every 3 years for at least 25 years.

E) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy with cervical biopsies in 6 months might be recommended in patients ≥ 25 years of age with any grade of CIN who underwent ablation or loop excision with clear margins, like this patient. However, this procedure is only indicated after another test shows a positive result.
questions.hint: In patients who undergo a cervical excisional or ablative procedure and have clear margins, the appropriate test for follow-up is selected based on the patient's age.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 55 years
Sex: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: annual check-up
History of Present Illness:


postmenopausal; last menstrual period 5 years ago
no abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge
no history of abnormal Pap smears
no history of HPV infection

Past Medical History:
type 2 diabetes mellitus, well-controlled with diet and exercise
Medications:
none
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.8°C(98.2°F)
77/min
14/min
112/78 mm Hg
98% on RA
170 cm(5 ft 7 in)
86 kg(191 lb)
30 kg/m2




Appearance: in no distress
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated
Extremities: no edema or tenderness
Neurologic: no abnormalities; alert and fully oriented

Diagnostic Studies

Pap smear: endometrial cells with no cytological abnormalities

human papillomavirus (HPV) test: negative


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An excisional method such as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) may be performed in patients with HSIL (CIN2 or CIN3) confirmed with colposcopy and cervical biopsy or in patients ≥ 25 years of age with abnormal cervical cancer screening results and a high risk of CIN3. LEEP is not indicated for patients with normal cervical cytology and a negative HPV test.

B) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy with cervical biopsy is performed in patients < 25 years of age with cytology findings of a high-grade lesion (e.g., cytological HSIL, atypical glandular cells) and is a reasonable diagnostic approach for patients ≥ 25 years of age with a high immediate risk of lesions that are more severe than CIN3 (e.g., endocervical adenocarcinoma in situ). Cervical biopsy is not necessary for patients with only benign endometrial cells on cervical cytology and a negative HPV test.

C) CORRECT:

Endometrial sampling is the most appropriate method for further evaluation of postmenopausal patients with benign endometrial cells on Pap smear to exclude endometrial pathology. Asymptomatic premenopausal patients with benign endometrial cells detected on screening do not require further evaluation.

Endometrial sampling is also indicated to rule out endometrial cancer in nonpregnant patients aged ≥ 35 years with atypical glandular cells (AGC) on cytology and in nonpregnant patients aged < 35 years with AGCs and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial neoplasia (e.g., obesity, chronic anovulation).

D) INCORRECT:

As endometrial cells are an abnormal Pap smear finding in postmenopausal individuals, continuing with regular monitoring (e.g., repeating HPV/Pap co-testing in 5 years) is not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient.
questions.hint: Endometrial cells are typically a benign cytology finding, but in postmenopausal individuals, they may indicate underlying endometrial pathology such as hyperplasia or cancer.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 3) undergoes a colposcopic evaluation for a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion that was detected on a routine Pap test. Cervical biopsy results from that evaluation confirm the presence of a microinvasive squamous-cell carcinoma of the cervix. Endocervical canal sampling is negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Concurrent chemoradiation therapy is the primary treatment of choice for disease stages with a high risk of recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy can be an option for medically inoperable patients and for patients who refuse surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapy, without concurrent radiation therapy, is reserved mainly for patients with recurrent or metastatic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic lymph-node dissection is recommended for patients with lymphovascular invasion on biopsy.

E) CORRECT:

Very early stages of cervical cancer are often asymptomatic, and squamous-cell carcinomas comprise about 80% of all cases. Treatment options depend on careful clinical evaluation and staging. Cervical cold-knife conization, also known as cone biopsy, is necessary to evaluate the depth and stage of the disease.

If the cone biopsy shows negative margins and the patient wishes to preserve her fertility, observation alone is acceptable. Positive margins warrant either repeat cone biopsy or radical trachelectomy (i.e., surgical removal of the cervix).

Key learning point: The correct initial management for a microinvasive squamous-cell carcinoma biopsy of the cervix is cervical cold-knife conization.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents for a routine Pap test. She had a normal Pap test at age 21 and reports a total of seven lifetime male partners. She has been monogamous with one male partner for the past 6 months. She denies any irregular vaginal bleeding and uses oral contraceptive pills for birth control.
Evaluation of the Pap test reveals atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, and a reflexive human papillomavirus test is positive.
What is the best next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Repeat human papillomavirus testing alone in 12 months
Repeat cervical cytology alone in 12 months
Repeat cervical cytology and human papillomavirus testing in 12 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HPV testing alone is not recommended in the management of abnormal cervical cytology.

B) CORRECT:

Recommendations for managing cervical cytology abnormalities depend on the patient’s age and the grade of the abnormality. In this case, the patient is <25 years of age and has atypical squamous cells of unknown significance (ASCUS) with positive testing for human papillomavirus (HPV). This is considered a low-grade cytologic abnormality (along with low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions and ASCUS with no HPV testing).

In women <25 years of age, low-grade cytologic abnormalities are likely to regress spontaneously without proceeding to cancer, so they can be followed relatively conservatively — with repeat cytology alone at 1 year and 2 years after the initial abnormal result. If the abnormal results persist at either assessment or if higher-grade cytologic abnormalities are found, colposcopy should be performed.

In women 25 years or older, a risk-based approach is recommended, with appropriate intervention tailored to the patient’s immediate and 5-year risk of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) grade 3, adenocarcinoma in situ, or cervical cancer (collectively referred to as CIN3+). This risk can be estimated using published tables and is primarily based on historical and current cytology and HPV results. Colposcopy is recommended for those designated as high risk for CIN3+ (immediate risk, ≥4%), whereas repeat screening may be appropriate for those at lower risk. The recommended interval for repeat screening (1, 3, or 5 years) depends on the patient’s 5-year risk for CIN3+.

Key learning point: Women younger than 25 years of age whose Pap test reveals atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance or low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions and whose human papillomavirus test is positive should undergo repeat cytology screening in 12 months.

C) INCORRECT:

In women <25 years of age, low-grade cytologic abnormalities are likely to regress spontaneously without proceeding to cancer, so they can be followed relatively conservatively — with repeat cytology alone at 1 year and 2 years after the initial abnormal result. Women with abnormal cervical cytology should not resume the normal screening interval (3 years for women ages 21 to 29) until they have had adequate follow-up at more frequent intervals.

D) INCORRECT:

Cotesting with cervical cytology and HPV testing is not recommended for women under the age of 30 unless a cervical intraepithelial neoplasm is being followed.

E) INCORRECT:

In women <25 years of age, low-grade cytologic abnormalities are likely to regress spontaneously without proceeding to cancer, so they can be followed relatively conservatively — with repeat cytology alone at 1 year and 2 years after the initial abnormal result. If the abnormal results persist at either assessment or if higher-grade cytologic abnormalities are found, colposcopy should be performed.

questions.text:
A healthy 25-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents to discuss contraceptive options. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and reports a lifetime total of eight male partners and two female partners. She had a negative chlamydia screen at age 19 but has never had screening for cervical cancer. She received two doses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine before age 18.
After counseling, she decides to use an intrauterine device for contraception and agrees to undergo HPV testing. The test comes back negative for HPV.
What follow-up care is most appropriate for this patient regarding cervical cancer screening?

choices.text: Perform cervical cytology and HPV testing in 7 years
Perform cervical cytology and HPV testing in one year
Repeat HPV testing in one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the HPV vaccine has been shown to prevent high-grade cervical lesions, recipients of this vaccine should still undergo routine cervical cancer screening as recommended by guidelines.

B) INCORRECT:

No guidelines recommend repeating testing one year after a negative HPV test, nor do they recommend waiting 7 years to test or stopping cervical cancer screening altogether, as these approaches would likely miss many cases of cervical cancer.

C) CORRECT:

Several guidelines are currently available regarding screening for cervical cancer in average-risk women. The American Cancer Society (ACS) no longer recommends screening women for cervical cancer before age 25, but all other guidelines recommend starting at age 21. Recommendations regarding specific screening modalities vary considerably across guidelines, particularly in terms of human papillomavirus (HPV) testing in women <30 years of age.

This patient underwent primary HPV testing at age 25, which is an option recommended by ACS and reasonable to consider according to ACOG and ASCCP. Given the patient’s initial negative result, repeat HPV testing is indicated in 3 to 5 years, depending on the specific guideline being followed. Although the HPV vaccine has been shown to prevent high-grade cervical lesions, recipients of this vaccine should still undergo routine cervical cancer screening as recommended by guidelines.

See “Age-appropriate cervical cancer screening for individuals at average risk” table.

Key learning point: Depending on the specific guideline being followed, screening for cervical cancer for women younger than age 30 can start at either age 21 or age 25 and consist of either a Pap test every 3 years or primary HPV testing every 3 to 5 years.

D) INCORRECT:

No guidelines recommend repeating testing one year after a negative HPV test, nor do they recommend waiting 7 years to test or stopping cervical cancer screening altogether, as these approaches would likely miss many cases of cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

No guidelines recommend repeating testing one year after a negative HPV test, nor do they recommend waiting 7 years to test or stopping cervical cancer screening altogether, as these approaches would likely miss many cases of cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. A Pap smear 4 years ago showed no abnormalities. She was treated for a chlamydia infection at 22 years of age. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A Pap smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An endometrial biopsy is recommended for all nonpregnant individuals ≥ 35 years of age with atypical glandular cells (AGCs) or adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) to rule out endometrial cancer. Endometrial biopsy is also recommended for nonpregnant individuals < 35 years of age with AGCs or AIS and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial cancer. This patient has atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, and therefore endometrial biopsy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Expedited excisional treatment (e.g., with loop electrosurgical excision procedure) is indicated for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required. In addition, as this patient has a low-grade cervical cytology, it is unlikely that excisional treatment will be required.

C) CORRECT:

If the initial primary HPV test or cytology-alone test is positive, reflex triage testing (i.e., cytology if HPV testing is positive and HPV testing if cytology is positive) should be performed for risk stratification. In patients with positive cytology-alone screening, reflex high-risk HPV genotyping is indicated to assess for HPV 16 or HPV 18 infection. Recommendations for further follow-up are based on the estimated risk for CIN3+.

If atypical glandular cells are found on initial cytology, reflex HPV testing is not required, as management is independent of HPV status.

D) INCORRECT:

Performing cytology in 3 years is the standard screening interval for cytology-alone screening for cervical cancer. This would be appropriate if this patient's cytology results were normal. However, this patient has positive cytology and the immediate risk of CIN3+ must be determined before deciding whether it is appropriate to resume routine screening.

E) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy and cervical biopsy may be considered for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required.
questions.hint: In patients with positive cytology, an additional step is required to assess the immediate risk of CIN3+.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. Her last visit was 3 years ago. She feels well. One year ago, she underwent a bilateral salpingectomy after the delivery of her third child. She does not take any medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A Pap smear shows a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. HPV testing is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Cytology and HPV testing after 12 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeat cytology (Pap smear) at three months is only indicated in cases in which the Pap smear is found unsatisfactory for evaluation. This is not the case in this patient, as a finding of HSIL has already been established based on her Pap smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Expedited treatment is appropriate in patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. While ablation is one possible treatment option, another treatment is preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

One-year follow-up with cytology and HPV testing is appropriate for patients with a low immediate risk of CIN3+ (e.g., low-grade cytology and negative HPV testing). For patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+, one-year follow-up is not appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+, expedited treatment (i.e., treatment without a preceding colposcopy with cervical biopsy and histological confirmation) is preferred. Excisional treatment (e.g., loop electrosurgical excision procedure) is preferred over ablation because it provides a tissue sample, and histopathological examination can assess margin status and allows for the detection of higher grade abnormalities. Performing a colposcopy with cervical biopsy before treatment is also a reasonable approach for patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+.

E) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy with cervical biopsy is an acceptable approach in patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. However, endometrial biopsy is not indicated in this patient. Endometrial biopsy is indicated in patients aged ≥ 35 years with atypical glandular cells on cytology or adenocarcinoma in situ. For patients aged < 35 years with these findings, endometrial biopsy is recommended if the patient also has abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial neoplasia (e.g., obesity, chronic anovulation).
questions.hint: A high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) on cytology with positive HPV testing is a predictor of a high immediate risk of CIN3+.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine gynecological examination. She feels well. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 3 to 5 days with normal flow. Her last menstrual period was 20 days ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 40 years. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and occasionally drinks a glass of wine with dinner. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A Pap smear shows atypical glandular cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform colposcopy with endocervical and endometrial sampling
Perform a diagnostic loop electrosurgical excision

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One-year follow-up is appropriate for patients with a low immediate risk of CIN3+ lesions (e.g., patients with low-grade cytology and negative HPV testing) but should include both cytology and HPV testing. Additionally, the presence of AGCs on cytology should raise concern for endometrial cancer, making a different step more appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Colposcopy with endocervical sampling is appropriate for all nonpregnant patients with AGCs to rule out cervical cancer, regardless of HPV test results. In addition, endometrial sampling should be performed in nonpregnant patients with AGCs who are ≥ 35 years of age and in nonpregnant patients aged < 35 years with AGCs and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial neoplasia (e.g., obesity, chronic anovulation) to rule out endometrial cancer.

Endocervical and endometrial sampling are contraindicated in pregnancy because of the increased risk of complications (e.g., cervical or membrane perforation, pregnancy loss).

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic excisional procedures such as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) are indicated in patients with a very high immediate risk of CIN 3+ lesions based on initial cytology and HPV testing. This patient has AGCs and therefore a different step should be performed before an excisional procedure is considered.

D) INCORRECT:

HPV testing is not required for patients with AGCs, as HPV status does not influence the course of management. HPV testing may be performed during the initial routine screening for cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with AGCs on Pap smear should urgently undergo colposcopy with endocervical sampling to rule out cervical squamous intraepithelial lesions and cervical adenocarcinoma in situ. However, in patients ≥ 35 years of age with AGCs on Pap smear, an additional procedure should be performed.
questions.hint: Consider the age of the patient and the cytology findings of atypical glandular cells (AGCs) to determine the next best step.

questions.text: A healthy 25-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents to discuss contraceptive options. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and reports a lifetime total of eight male partners and two female partners. She had a negative chlamydia screen at age 19 but has never had screening for cervical cancer. She received two doses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine before age 18. After counseling, she decides to use an intrauterine device for contraception and agrees to undergo HPV testing. The test comes back negative for HPV. What follow-up care is most appropriate for this patient regarding cervical cancer screening?

choices.text: Perform cervical cytology and HPV testing in 7 years
Perform cervical cytology and HPV testing in one year
Repeat HPV testing in one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the HPV vaccine has been shown to prevent high-grade cervical lesions, recipients of this vaccine should still undergo routine cervical cancer screening as recommended by guidelines.

B) INCORRECT:

No guidelines recommend repeating testing one year after a negative HPV test, nor do they recommend waiting 7 years to test or stopping cervical cancer screening altogether, as these approaches would likely miss many cases of cervical cancer.

C) CORRECT:

Several guidelines are currently available regarding screening for cervical cancer in average-risk women. The American Cancer Society (ACS) no longer recommends screening women for cervical cancer before age 25, but all other guidelines recommend starting at age 21.

This patient underwent primary HPV testing at age 25, which is an option recommended by ACS and reasonable to consider according to ACOG and ASCCP. Given the patient’s initial negative result, repeat HPV testing is indicated in 3 to 5 years, depending on the specific guideline being followed. Although the HPV vaccine has been shown to prevent high-grade cervical lesions, recipients of this vaccine should still undergo routine cervical cancer screening as recommended by guidelines.

See “Age-appropriate cervical cancer screening for individuals at average risk” table.

Key learning point: Depending on the specific guideline being followed, screening for cervical cancer for women younger than age 30 can start at either age 21 or age 25 and consist of either a Pap test every 3 years or primary HPV testing every 3 to 5 years.

D) INCORRECT:

No guidelines recommend repeating testing one year after a negative HPV test, nor do they recommend waiting 7 years to test or stopping cervical cancer screening altogether, as these approaches would likely miss many cases of cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

No guidelines recommend repeating testing one year after a negative HPV test, nor do they recommend waiting 7 years to test or stopping cervical cancer screening altogether, as these approaches would likely miss many cases of cervical cancer.
questions.hint: Recommendations regarding specific screening modalities vary considerably across guidelines, particularly in terms of human papillomavirus (HPV) testing in women <30 years of age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman presents for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Pap smear now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every year, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF, a Pap smear every 3 years in individuals with a cervix who are 21–29 years of age is an acceptable screening method for cervical cancer. However, an additional test is required as a part of cervical cancer screening starting at the age of 30 years. In addition, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, this patient should now receive HPV testing along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should not be repeated annually because more frequent testing does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

C) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening every 5 years starting at 30 years of age. However, when screening every 5 years, the protocol requires another test in addition to the Pap smear. If the additional test cannot be performed, a Pap smear should be taken every 3 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

E) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years for individuals with a cervix who are 30–65 years of age and a solitary Pap smear every 3 years for those between 21–29 years of age. This guidance differs from the recently updated ASCCP, ACS, and ACOG guidelines, which recommend that those aged 25–65 years undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (where available) or HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years. All guidelines recommend a solitary Pap smear every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable.

Regarding breast cancer, mammography is rarely useful in younger patients, who have naturally denser breast tissue. According to the USPSTF, breast cancer screening with mammography should be performed every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Screening can be started earlier in patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancer. Breast cancer screening recommendations may differ between medical organizations (e.g., ACOG, ACS). Consult our table “Breast cancer screening for individuals at average risk” for the most up-to-date information on breast cancer screening recommendations.

Whenever the information required to determine the correct answer for an NBME question involves a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF recommendations.
questions.hint: This patient is healthy and requires the standard screening tests for her age group and risk stratification according to USPSTF guidelines.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Her last Pap smear, performed 4 years ago, was normal. She was treated for chlamydia infection at age 22. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She has a 6-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. A Pap smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

If the initial primary HPV test or cytology-alone test is positive, reflex triage testing (i.e., cytology if HPV testing is positive and HPV testing if cytology is positive) should be performed for risk stratification. In patients with positive cytology-alone screening, reflex high-risk HPV genotyping is indicated to assess for HPV 16 or HPV 18 infection. Recommendations for further follow-up are based on the estimated risk for CIN3+.

If atypical glandular cells are found on initial cytology, reflex HPV testing is not required, as management is independent of HPV status.

Key learning point: For women with atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance on Pap smear, reflex high-risk HPV testing is the recommended next step to guide further management.

B) INCORRECT:

Performing cytology in 3 years is the standard screening interval for cytology-alone screening for cervical cancer. This would be appropriate if this patient's cytology results were normal. However, this patient has positive cytology and the immediate risk of CIN3+ must be determined before deciding whether it is appropriate to resume routine screening.

C) INCORRECT:

An endometrial biopsy is recommended for all nonpregnant individuals ≥ 35 years of age with atypical glandular cells (AGCs) or adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) to rule out endometrial cancer. Endometrial biopsy is also recommended for nonpregnant individuals < 35 years of age with AGCs or AIS and abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial cancer. This patient has atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, and therefore endometrial biopsy is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Expedited excisional treatment (e.g., with loop electrosurgical excision procedure) is indicated for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required. In addition, as this patient has a low-grade cervical cytology, it is unlikely that excisional treatment will be required.

E) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy and cervical biopsy may be considered for women with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. This patient's immediate risk of CIN3+ has not been assessed, and therefore a different step in management is required.
questions.hint: In patients with positive cytology, an additional step is required to assess the immediate risk of CIN3+.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. Her last visit was 3 years ago. She reports feeling well. One year ago, she had a bilateral salpingectomy following the delivery of her third child. She does not take any medications. Physical examination is normal. A Pap smear shows a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, and HPV testing is positive. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Cytology and HPV testing after 12 months.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+, expedited treatment (i.e., treatment without a preceding colposcopy with cervical biopsy and histological confirmation) is preferred. Excisional treatment (e.g., loop electrosurgical excision procedure) is preferred over ablation because it provides a tissue sample, and histopathological examination can assess margin status and allows for the detection of higher grade abnormalities. Performing a colposcopy with cervical biopsy before treatment is also a reasonable approach for patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+.

Key learning point: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion with positive HPV testing requires expedited excisional treatment, such as a loop electrosurgical excision procedure, to obtain tissue for histopathological evaluation and rule out invasive disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeat cytology (Pap smear) at three months is only indicated in cases in which the Pap smear is found unsatisfactory for evaluation. This is not the case in this patient, as a finding of HSIL has already been established based on her Pap smear.

C) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy with cervical biopsy is an acceptable approach in patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. However, endometrial biopsy is not indicated in this patient. Endometrial biopsy is indicated in patients aged ≥ 35 years with atypical glandular cells on cytology or adenocarcinoma in situ. For patients aged < 35 years with these findings, endometrial biopsy is recommended if the patient also has abnormal uterine bleeding or risk factors for endometrial neoplasia (e.g., obesity, chronic anovulation).

D) INCORRECT:

One-year follow-up with cytology and HPV testing is appropriate for patients with a low immediate risk of CIN3+ (e.g., low-grade cytology and negative HPV testing). For patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+, one-year follow-up is not appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Expedited treatment is appropriate in patients with a high immediate risk of CIN3+. While ablation is one possible treatment option, another treatment is preferred.
questions.hint: A high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) on cytology with positive HPV testing is a predictor of a high immediate risk of CIN3+.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the gynecology clinic for her first cervical cancer screening. She reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or dyspareunia. She became sexually active at age 16 years and has had two lifetime sexual partners. She uses oral contraceptive pills for birth control. She has no significant medical history. Her mother was treated for cervical cancer at age 45 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows no cervical lesions or discharge. A photomicrograph of a cervical sample from a Pap smear is shown. HPV testing is negative for high-risk HPV. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Formerly, the management approach for abnormal cervical cancer screening was determined by test results alone. Recent recommendations have shifted to a risk-based approach. Risk calculators can be used to estimate the immediate risk of CIN3. If this risk is ≥ 4%, colposcopy and cervical biopsy or expedited treatment may be used. If this risk is < 4%, surveillance with HPV-based testing every 1–5 years is recommended.

However, certain patient groups (e.g., women < 25 years of age) should still be treated based on test results. In patients < 25 years of age with HSIL on cytology, colposcopy and biopsy are indicated. Expedited treatment (without a preceding colposcopic biopsy and histological confirmation) is not recommended at this age as most cervical abnormalities regress spontaneously. Low-grade lesions (LSIL or ASC-US) in patients < 25 years of age can be managed with cytology-alone screening annually for the next two years.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial sampling after Pap smear is indicated in postmenopausal women with benign endometrial cells on cytology but not for HSIL.

C) INCORRECT:

While observation with repeat cytology may be appropriate for certain low-grade lesions (e.g., ASC-US, LSIL) in women < 25 years of age, it is not recommended for HSIL. HSIL has a much higher risk of progression to invasive disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Expedited treatment (without a preceding colposcopic biopsy and histological confirmation), e.g., immediate loop electrosurgical excision, is not recommended in women < 25 years of age, even with an HSIL. Most cervical abnormalities at this age regress spontaneously. Excisional procedures carry risks (e.g., cervical incompetence, preterm birth) and are reserved for high-grade lesions that have been confirmed on biopsy or when colposcopic evaluation cannot rule out invasive disease.

E) INCORRECT:

HPV vaccination is recommended for the prevention of HPV infection and related cervical dysplasia and cancer but is not a treatment for cytological abnormalities. This patient already has HSIL, so vaccination is not a priority.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows a sheet of small abnormal epithelial cells with irregular nuclear contours, a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and irregular clumped chromatin. There is a dyskeratotic cell within the clump of abnormal cells. These findings are characteristic of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL).

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic for an annual wellness visit. She is asymptomatic and has no significant past medical history. She had a normal Pap smear three years ago and has no record of HPV co-testing. She reports being sexually active with a new partner for the past six months. Physical examination is normal, and routine labs are within normal limits.
She asks whether she requires cervical cancer screening at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Repeat Pap smear in one year
Perform Pap test with HPV co-testing now

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cervical cancer screening guidelines recommend that women aged 21 to 29 undergo a Pap test every 3 years, regardless of sexual history. This patient had her last Pap smear 3 years ago, aligning with the recommended interval. HPV co-testing is not advised before age 30 due to the high prevalence of transient HPV infections in younger women, which can lead to unnecessary interventions. Therefore, obtaining a Pap test now is consistent with guidelines and minimizes the risk of over-diagnosis and overtreatment.

Key learning point: Women aged 21 to 29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, and a normal result 3 years ago indicates that a repeat Pap test is due.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeating a Pap smear in one year is not recommended for women aged 21 to 29 with a normal Pap result, even with a new sexual partner. Guidelines advise screening every 3 years, as more frequent testing can lead to unnecessary interventions due to transient HPV infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Deferring screening until age 30 is incorrect for women aged 21 to 29, who should have a Pap smear every 3 years. This patient, at 26, falls within this age group and had a normal Pap smear 3 years ago. The presence of a new sexual partner does not alter the recommended screening interval.

D) INCORRECT:

For women aged 21 to 29, guidelines recommend a Pap smear every 3 years without HPV co-testing, as transient HPV infections are common and can lead to unnecessary follow-up. HPV co-testing is generally reserved for women aged 30 and older.
